text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is David Carson. And David Cruz. Few characters in either science fiction or fantasy have been as fascinating to readers as Conan the Barbarian. Conan is the creation of Robert E. Howard, a writer of the 1930s who lived in Cross Plains, Texas. Howard filled the pulp magazines of his day with westerns, detective stories, horror stories, science fantasy, just about anything that would sell. But he became best known for his tales of heroic fantasy, particularly the ones that involved Conan. Conan was a giant barbarian who lived a swashbuckling life in the mythical Hyborian age that Howard created. There is nothing fancy or subtle about Conan. He survives and flourishes by pure muscle and swordplay. Howard's writing was colorful and exciting and perfectly matched his hero. Howard committed suicide in 1936 at the age of 30. He left a number of unfinished Conan manuscripts and story ideas. And the character of Conan was so appealing to readers that authors have recently been writing new material on him or finishing Howard's own incomplete stories. Noted science fiction and fantasy author L. Sprague de Camp has written Conan stories and become interested enough in Howard's life to write a biography of him. We asked de Camp if Howard was anything like Conan. Well, everybody knows that Conan is an idealization of Howard. In other words, the kind of person that Howard thought he would have liked to have been the ruthless, domineering, footloose, irresponsible adventurer. Actually, Robert was no respecter of laws and regulations. But the key word here is idealization. De Camp says Howard and Conan were nothing alike. Actually, Robert was just the opposite type. Except for hot tempers and chivalrous attitude toward women, they had nothing in common. Robert Howard was shy, bookish, compassionate, extremely polite, and socially timid, and so law-abiding that he wouldn't cut across the neighbor's lot even, although everybody else across the lanes did. He was just about as different from the character Conan in the stories as a person could be. De Camp believes Howard yearned to live in a past age, some more heroic time than the present. Well, Robert was always talking a lot about how he wished that he thought he'd have been, really in his element, if he'd been born on the Texan frontier in the 19th century, or in some barbarian society like the ancient Gauls or Goths or somebody. Well, I don't, I think he'd have had a very unpleasant surprise. Because it wasn't, it wasn't his temperament at all. He was a, he was a shy, bookish introvert. Finally, De Camp reveals that Howard had a serious mental problem. He had an outsized monkey on his back, and he was, he was doomed from some way back. He planned his suicide ever since he was a little boy. He told his mother when he was a little kitty that when, Mama, when you die, I want to die with you. And the foolish woman, I think, probably sort of giggled and encouraged him. It was long planned, and several people knew about it. But they didn't do anything. The only thing you could have done with Robert was, if you'd gotten him to a good shrink early enough, quite a good many years before he actually killed himself, why, something might have been done. But that, of course, is uncertain. Howard wrote some 21 Conan stories, most of which appeared in Weird Tales in the 1930s. Only one novel, Conan the Conqueror, was published, and that was some time after Howard's death. More next time about Robert E. Howard. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. and Wild Darin bike 311 at Purdue who was a fabulous geezer, doing one grant as well. And we'll be playing the science on Venice. Like the designing반 period for 19 months, while a military architect hired a Fryzo, the tails atyer hiper, But this is my own time. moon speed didn't start on the surface, but you don't celebrate them as long as possible. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is David Cruz and David Carson. There are subcategories coming under the general headings of science fiction and fantasy. One of the most popular these days is heroic fantasy. It's sometimes called sword and sorcery, a term that almost serves as a definition for the genre. It deals with heroic barbarians swinging large bloody swords and sorcerers conjuring up all manner of demons. And as we've said, it's popular nowadays, particularly the Conan stories of Robert E. Howard. We asked an authority on heroic fantasy, L. Spray de Camp, to tell us why the form is so fascinating to readers. I think that part of the popularity of the genre was a reaction to certain trends in fiction following the Second World War, such as the fondness for heavily subjective psychological or psychiatric stories, very sentimental stories, stories glorifying the little man, the anti-hero, that hopeless little jerk who can't do anything right and who has no brains or brawn or character and whose only function is to suffer and suffer. Well, I think people got sort of tired of that after a while. So they then, between the paperback publication of the Conan stories, for which I can claim the credit, I'm the one who sold them, and the paperback publication of Tolkien's Lord of the Rings, which was the other major factor in launching this boom, why that got people to reading heroic fantasy on a large scale, which they are still doing. De Camp has written his own sword and sorcery, but he's also worked on the Conan material of Robert E. Howard. He tells us how he was introduced to Howard's stories of Conan. ...York in, uh, it was around the end of 1950, and, uh, let me see, I think it was, uh, I think it was a naval war game at Pratt's apartment or something. No, it wasn't. It was a party at Pratt's apartment. And, uh, he handed me a copy of Conan the Conqueror, found in hardback, published by Nome Press. And he said, here, take this along. I think you might find it interesting. I don't care much for it myself, but who knows? So I took it. It seems that, uh, Martin had, um, by inadvertence sent, uh, Fletcher two review copies, and Fletcher gave me one. So I started reading it on the train going home and was hooked right away. Kept on until I'd read the thing through, and then I read it through again. Howard died in the 1930s, but De Camp became so involved with the character of Conan that he started to edit some of Howard's papers and to write his own Conan stories. And then a year later, I found some, I learned about some unpublished Conan manuscripts in the custody of, uh, the agent for the Howard Literary Estate. And, uh, I read them, and arrangements were made with the Howard Ayers and, uh, the agent for me to edit them for public, and arrange for publication, and on, things have, uh, things have gone on, uh, on and on, and build up from that. De Camp has written original Conan material, but he's also finished incomplete Howard stories and edited others. De Camp is also technical advisor to a movie on Conan that will premiere this week. It's entitled Conan the Barbarian, and it will show you what heroic fantasy is all about. More about Robert E. Howard next time. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show, coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is David Carson. And David Cruz. Robert E. Howard, the creator of Conan the Barbarian, was a paradox. He was brought up on the arid plains of west central Texas, lived in the small country town of Cross Plains, and hardly did any traveling, and he died by his own hand at the age of 30. Yet Howard wrote heroic stories that were set in the mythical age after the fall of Atlantis. He was fascinated with the misty, cold northern landscape in which he set his tales. Conan, his greatest creation, was a barbarian from the north, a giant who strode across the Hyborian age wielding a bloody broadsword. But Howard's life was a quiet one. He was introverted, bookish, and shy. As far as we know, he was never in a brawl or fight of any kind. Why did Howard create Conan and place him in a mythical northern landscape? What sort of mind would conceive of a barbarian hero, a loner who spurned civilization? We spoke with Dr. Charlotte Laughlin, a professor at Howard Payne University in Brownwood, Texas, not far from Howard's home in Cross Plains. Dr. Laughlin is intimate with Howard's life and has done research for her Howard biography. She believes there are some reasons for Howard's obsession with Conan. I think that, again, it was a sort of explanation for why he did not fit in with other people. He liked to believe, I am the last barbarian. It's because, and my type will prevail. He liked to believe that the other people had a veneer of civilization on them that got them away from the basics that were really important. And if you've read his correspondence with Lovecraft, they had long arguments about the physical versus the intellectual needs of a society. And Howard would say that in the tough country where he lived, you had to be physically fit. And he spent a great deal of his life, his adult life, trying to be physically fit, boxing and working out and that sort of thing. Howard also was fascinated with the legendary past of Britain, especially with the savage Picts and the early heroes of Celtic myth. Some of his Conan stories, such as Across the Dark River, have ancient Britain as their setting. We asked Dr. Laughlin why Howard was so drawn to this material. He claimed that he was full-blood Irish and they were the Irish kings like some other people we know claim to be. But there's no evidence that he certainly was not full-blood Irish. People have traced his genealogy. But this was part of his image of himself. He was trying to project other people and trying to create for himself. There again, he wrote at one time that he wrote about the barren, cold, windswept, damp areas even though he lived here. I think that again might be a sort of wish fulfillment. Who wouldn't like to be someplace where it's cold on a day like this? He wanted to be away from where he was because I don't think we can underestimate the anger and frustration that was boiling around in Robert Howard all the time. I see it in all of his poetry and a great deal of his fiction. Cross Plains neighbors say that he had a, there was a big tree stump out by his yard and I believe it was a sledgehammer not an axe. And sometimes in the middle of the day he would go out there, you know, and you could just see that he was so tense and he would take that sledgehammer and he would just wham it and wham it and wham it on this tree stump. That a tremendous amount of anger he didn't fit in with other people. He wanted to be somewhere else so he wrote about something that was like nothing he had experienced. Howard wrote reams of fantasy in the pulp era of the 1930s, most of it for weird tales. We asked Dr. Laughlin why Howard wrote fantasy. Did he have the talent to write more realistic fiction that might have gotten him out of the pulp ghetto? He may have had the talent but I certainly don't believe he was capable of writing realistic fiction. He was not that closely tied to reality himself. I don't believe he ever could have written realistic novels. He had to write fantasies of some sort. More about Robert E. Howard next time. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. There with no buat form of don't be Hostess in son Long하�uler. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Jack Scott also comments on Howard's unusual personality. Howard was a little on the odd side. He wasn't intimate with very many people. He was rather aloof. But he was a big, robust man. To me, he was a combination of Edgar Allen Poe and Jack London, if you can imagine that two together. In 1936, when Howard's mother was dying of a terminal illness, Howard took his own life. I remember the morning he killed himself very well. I heard on the street that Robert Howard had just shot himself. I immediately jumped in my car and ran down there and got down there. A few neighbors had gathered. It wasn't generally known over the town, but the old justice of the peace was standing there on the gallery, the front porch. When I walked up, he called me and said, Come here, Jack. And I stepped up there and he took me into the bedroom. And he pointed to an old Underwood typewriter. It had four lines written on it there. And Howard had, when he had been told that his mother wouldn't live throughout the day, he went to this typewriter, wrote these four lines, walked outside, sat down in his car and shot his head off. And this old JP asked me what these four lines meant. They said, I'm sure you've read them all flat all done, so lift me on the pyre. The feast is over. The lamps expire. More about Robert E. Howard next time. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show, Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is David Carson. And David Cruz. Will Conan the Barbarian ever die, or will he go on forever? A large portion of the fantasy section of bookstores these days is filled with books about Conan, the heroic barbarian created by the late Robert E. Howard. Howard devised a mythical error for his hero and called it the Hyborian Age. The period falls somewhere between the fall of Atlantis and the beginnings of recorded history. Conan is a giant barbarian from Cimmeria, a region to the north of the more civilized Hyborian kingdoms. With his huge sword, he is an irresistible force that no man can stand up to. Howard wrote some 21 Conan stories in the 1930s, most published in the pulp magazine Weird Tales. They trace the life of the barbarian from his teenage years to his later maturity when he became a king. The tales are full of lusty, bloody adventure, pure escape fantasy that appeals to man's primal instincts. Conan battles warriors, sorcerers, and monsters of all shapes. He's a thief, a soldier, a swashbuckling pirate, and a king. The Conan stories are so popular that a number of publishing houses have been putting them out. And a number of different authors have been writing Conan stories. Howard left many gaps in the life of Conan, and various contemporary writers have been filling those gaps with original stories. L. Sprague de Camp was the first author to do that. These stories done by other writers are called pastiches, and established writers such as de Camp, Andrew J. Offit, Poole Anderson, Lynn Carter, and Bjorn Nyberg have done them. We went to Robert E. Howard's home territory, the Brownwood Cross Plains area of west central Texas, to speak with Dr. Charlotte Laughlin and Dr. William Kreider. Dr. Laughlin has done research for a biography of Howard, and Dr. Kreider teaches science fiction and fantasy at Howard Payne University. Dr. Kreider explains what a pastiche is. Well, in the sense that we've been talking about it, it's where one writer takes a character and a world, like the Hyborian age created by another writer, and writes new stories with the same character in the same setting. And he gets the full credit for the story, but the other writer has created the character and the historical setting. Also, de Camp did something similar, where he took incomplete Howard stories and changed them into Conan stories, which would be a pastiche of a slightly different kind, but it's the same principle operating. The biography of Howard, entitled Dark Valley Destiny, has been written by Al Sprague de Camp and his wife Catherine, and will probably be out sometime in the next year. The book will mainly be a psychological study of Howard, which attempts to explain why he wrote the kind of material he did. Conan has been so popular that a major movie about him, entitled Conan the Barbarian, is premiering this week across the country. It was filmed in Spain by director John Milius and produced by Dino de Laurentiis, and has muscle man Arnold Schwarzenegger playing Conan. Early reports indicate that it does a marvelous job of conveying the atmosphere of sword and sorcery essential to a Conan adventure. Loughlin and Kreider talk about the movie and about Conan's popularity. If this is a huge success, like Star Wars, let's say, that could give even more emphasis to this kind of thing, and we may see Howard going on forever with these pastiches being done by... I think it's possible that they would be continued, because the original idea was to fill out Conan's life, you know, have his life completely covered by the pastiches from, I don't know if he went to his boyhood, but certainly all of his adult life when he was an old King Conan. And it's already gone beyond that. They filled out his life, and then they're going back to, you know, this stage in his life. He did such and such. So certainly they're not going to stop with what would be the chronological life of Conan. So the potential to go on beyond is there. The potential to keep Conan alive and adventuring is definitely there. We should be hearing a lot more from Conan. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Organization formaalσm.com

This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is David Carson.
And David Cruz.
Few characters in either science fiction or fantasy have been as fascinating to readers as Conan the Barbarian.
Conan is the creation of Robert E. Howard, a writer of the 1930s who lived in Cross Plains, Texas.
Howard filled the pulp magazines of his day with westerns, detective stories, horror stories, science fantasy, just about anything that would sell.
But he became best known for his tales of heroic fantasy, particularly the ones that involved Conan.
Conan was a giant barbarian who lived a swashbuckling life in the mythical Hyborian age that Howard created.
There is nothing fancy or subtle about Conan.
He survives and flourishes by pure muscle and swordplay.
Howard's writing was colorful and exciting and perfectly matched his hero.
Howard committed suicide in 1936 at the age of 30.
He left a number of unfinished Conan manuscripts and story ideas.
And the character of Conan was so appealing to readers that authors have recently been writing new material on him or finishing Howard's own incomplete stories.
Noted science fiction and fantasy author L. Sprague de Camp has written Conan stories and become interested enough in Howard's life to write a biography of him.
We asked de Camp if Howard was anything like Conan.
Well, everybody knows that Conan is an idealization of Howard.
In other words, the kind of person that Howard thought he would have liked to have been the ruthless, domineering, footloose, irresponsible adventurer.
Actually, Robert was no respecter of laws and regulations.
But the key word here is idealization.
De Camp says Howard and Conan were nothing alike.
Actually, Robert was just the opposite type.
Except for hot tempers and chivalrous attitude toward women, they had nothing in common.
Robert Howard was shy, bookish, compassionate, extremely polite,
and socially timid,
and so law-abiding that he wouldn't cut across the neighbor's lot even,
although everybody else across the lanes did.
He was just about as different from the character Conan in the stories as a person could be.
De Camp believes Howard yearned to live in a past age,
some more heroic time than the present.
Well, Robert was always talking a lot about how he wished that he thought he'd have been,
really in his element, if he'd been born on the Texan frontier in the 19th century,
or in some barbarian society like the ancient Gauls or Goths or somebody.
Well, I don't, I think he'd have had a very unpleasant surprise.
Because it wasn't, it wasn't his temperament at all.
He was a, he was a shy, bookish introvert.
Finally, De Camp reveals that Howard had a serious mental problem.
He had an outsized monkey on his back, and he was, he was doomed from some way back.
He planned his suicide ever since he was a little boy.
He told his mother when he was a little kitty that when,
Mama, when you die, I want to die with you.
And the foolish woman, I think, probably sort of giggled and encouraged him.
It was long planned, and several people knew about it.
But they didn't do anything.
The only thing you could have done with Robert was,
if you'd gotten him to a good shrink early enough,
quite a good many years before he actually killed himself,
why, something might have been done.
But that, of course, is uncertain.
Howard wrote some 21 Conan stories,

Only one novel, Conan the Conqueror, was published,

A large portion of the fantasy section of bookstores these days is filled with books about Conan,
the heroic barbarian created by the late Robert E. Howard.
Howard devised a mythical error for his hero and called it the Hyborian Age.
The period falls somewhere between the fall of Atlantis and the beginnings of recorded history.
Conan is a giant barbarian from Cimmeria,
a region to the north of the more civilized Hyborian kingdoms.
With his huge sword, he is an irresistible force that no man can stand up to.
Howard wrote some 21 Conan stories in the 1930s,
most published in the pulp magazine Weird Tales.
They trace the life of the barbarian from his teenage years
to his later maturity when he became a king.
The tales are full of lusty, bloody adventure,
pure escape fantasy that appeals to man's primal instincts.
Conan battles warriors, sorcerers, and monsters of all shapes.
He's a thief, a soldier, a swashbuckling pirate, and a king.
The Conan stories are so popular that a number of publishing houses have been putting them out.
And a number of different authors have been writing Conan stories.
Howard left many gaps in the life of Conan,
and various contemporary writers have been filling those gaps with original stories.
L. Sprague de Camp was the first author to do that.
These stories done by other writers are called pastiches,
and established writers such as de Camp, Andrew J. Offit, Poole Anderson,
Lynn Carter, and Bjorn Nyberg have done them.
We went to Robert E. Howard's home territory,
the Brownwood Cross Plains area of west central Texas,
to speak with Dr. Charlotte Laughlin and Dr. William Kreider.
Dr. Laughlin has done research for a biography of Howard,
and Dr. Kreider teaches science fiction and fantasy at Howard Payne University.
Dr. Kreider explains what a pastiche is.
Well, in the sense that we've been talking about it,
it's where one writer takes a character and a world,
like the Hyborian age created by another writer,
and writes new stories with the same character in the same setting.
And he gets the full credit for the story,
but the other writer has created the character and the historical setting.
Also, de Camp did something similar,
where he took incomplete Howard stories
and changed them into Conan stories,
which would be a pastiche of a slightly different kind,
but it's the same principle operating.
The biography of Howard, entitled Dark Valley Destiny,
has been written by Al Sprague de Camp and his wife Catherine,
and will probably be out sometime in the next year.
The book will mainly be a psychological study of Howard,
which attempts to explain why he wrote the kind of material he did.
Conan has been so popular that a major movie about him,
entitled Conan the Barbarian,
is premiering this week across the country.
It was filmed in Spain by director John Milius
and produced by Dino de Laurentiis,
and has muscle man Arnold Schwarzenegger playing Conan.
Early reports indicate that it does a marvelous job
of conveying the atmosphere of sword and sorcery
essential to a Conan adventure.
Loughlin and Kreider talk about the movie
and about Conan's popularity.
If this is a huge success, like Star Wars, let's say,
that could give even more emphasis to this kind of thing,
and we may see Howard going on forever
with these pastiches being done by...
I think it's possible that they would be continued,
because the original idea was to fill out Conan's life,
you know, have his life completely covered by the pastiches from,
I don't know if he went to his boyhood,
but certainly all of his adult life
when he was an old King Conan.
And it's already gone beyond that.
They filled out his life,
and then they're going back to, you know,
this stage in his life.
He did such and such.
So certainly they're not going to stop
with what would be the chronological life of Conan.
So the potential to go on beyond is there.
The potential to keep Conan alive and adventuring
is definitely there.
We should be hearing a lot more from Conan.
